title: Gerry Arrigo
text:
Gerald William Arrigo (born June 12, 1941) is an American former <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> who appeared in 194 <a href="games%20pitched">games</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (<a href="MLB">MLB</a>) for the <a href="Minnesota%20Twins">Minnesota Twins</a>, <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a>, <a href="New%20York%20Mets">New York Mets</a> and <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a> between and . Arrigo was a <a href="left-handed">left-hander</a> who was listed as tall and weighed . He was a graduate of <a href="Harrison%20Technical%20High%20School">Harrison Technical High School</a> in his native city of <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>.
His pro career began in 1960 in the White Sox organization. But after only one season in the Class D <a href="Midwest%20League">Midwest League</a>, he was selected by the Twins in the first-year player draft then in effect. His first major league game occurred on June 12, 1961, when he <a href="starting%20pitcher">started</a> against the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a> at <a href="Fenway%20Park">Fenway Park</a>. After hurling a scoreless <a href="inning%20%28baseball%29">first inning</a>, he allowed three <a href="earned%20run">earned run</a>s on three <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a>, a <a href="base%20on%20balls">walk</a>, and a <a href="hit%20by%20pitch">hit batsman</a> in the second inning. He was charged with the Twins' eventual 10–8 loss. He worked in seven games for the 1961 Twins, then six total MLB games in and , which he spent primarily in <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor league baseball</a>.
Arrigo threw two one-hit games in his career. On June 26, 1964, he had a <a href="no%20hitter">no hitter</a> going against the White Sox until <a href="Mike%20Hershberger">Mike Hershberger</a> hit a <a href="single%20%28baseball%29">single</a> to center in the top of the ninth inning. His second one-hitter, which came on April 29, 1967, lacked the suspense of the first, as Arrigo gave up the only hit of the game to the <a href="New%20York%20Mets">New York Mets</a>' <a href="Jerry%20Grote">Jerry Grote</a> in the first inning.
He had his best all-around year in for the Reds, in his second tour of duty with the franchise. Appearing in 36 games (31 as starting pitcher) and 205 <a href="innings%20pitched">innings pitched</a>, his record was 12–10 with a 3.33 <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a> with 140 <a href="strikeouts">strikeouts</a> and five <a href="complete%20game">complete game</a>s.
Arrigo went on to play his final major league game with the White Sox, his original organization, on June 5, 1970. In 194 MLB games, with 80 starts, he compiled a 35–40 (4.14) record, with nine complete games, three <a href="shutout%20%28baseball%29">shutouts</a> and four <a href="save%20%28baseball%29">saves</a>. In 620 innings pitched, he allowed 605 hits and 291 bases on balls, striking out 433. He retired from pro ball in 1971.
